sn47.40:4.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you mindfulness meditation, the development of mindfulness meditation, and the practice that leads to the development of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.40:4.4: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.40:4.5: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.40:4.7: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.40:5.1: And what is the development of mindfulness meditation?
sn47.40:5.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to originate and vanish, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.40:5.5: principles as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to originate and vanish, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.40:5.6: This is called the development of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.40:6.1: And what is the practice that leads to the development of mindfulness meditation?
sn47.40:6.2: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
sn47.40:6.3: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
sn47.40:6.4: This is called the practice that leads to the development of mindfulness meditation.”
